        "226": "See generally Reisman &amp; Baker, supra note 58, at 37, 73–77 (discussing ways to regulate covert action); Jackamo, supra note 72, at 973–77; Barry, supra note 58 (basing his analysis of covert political action on just war theory); Damrosch, supra note 11, at 21. INDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2 intervenor be targeting an electoral process in support of “democratic” forces in an insufficiently democratic environment, the intervention could possibly be justified on those grounds.²²⁷ On the other hand, the intervention in a “democratic” electoral process could not be justified under international law.²²⁸ Almost needless to say, such a view cannot be reflective of current customary international law, as many states have never been able to lay claim to being a “democracy.”²²⁹ In fact, currently it seems that “democracy” is in retreat, with many societies seemingly preferring stability to democracy.²³⁰ It is therefore highly unlikely that these states would accept a rule in international law according to which an intervention in their electoral processes would be justified, but not vice versa.²³¹ Furthermore, such a hypothetical rule of international law is unsurprisingly bound to be seen as self-serving: a reversion to western exceptionalism on the basis of a putative rule that just so happens to justify Western behavior while protecting Western societies against similar actions.²³² Lastly, the ICJ, too, has in the past ²²⁷. Reisman &amp; Baker, supra note 58, at 75 (stating that interventions should also be judged on the basis of whether they were able “to increase the probability of the free choice of peoples about their government and political structure”); see Damrosch, supra note 11, at 21, 40–45 (limiting the right to intervene to target states where there is “a serious pattern of violation of political human rights” while acknowledging that “even a one-party-state may be able … to satisfy an emerging international standard of political participation”); see generally Loch K. Johnson, On Drawing a Bright Line for Covert Operations, 86 AM. J. INT'L L. 284, 288, 294, 296, 307 (1992) (arguing that intervening in a democratic society should be subject to more stringent rules than when the target society is non-democratic). ²²⁸. Damrosch, supra note 11, at 37–38; Ohlen, supra note 10, at 97. ²³⁰. Elizabeth A. Wilson, “People Power” and the Problem of Sovereignty in International Law, 26 DUKE J. COMPAR. &amp; INT'L L. 551, 577–79 (2016). ²³¹. Damrosch, supra note 11, at 37–38; Lahmann, supra note 2, at 220, 222–23. ²³². That no such distinction should be made is also implied by two former U.S. Presidents’ statements: President Gerald Ford and President Ronald Reagan. President Ford seems to have taken a similar view as far as treating like things like. In a news conference, he was asked (referencing Chile): “Mr. President, under what international law do we have the right to destabilize the constitutionally elected government of another country. And does the Soviet Union have a similar right to destabilize the Government of Canada, for example, or the United States?” To this, President Ford responded: “I’m not going to pass judgment on whether it is permitted or authorized under international law. It’s a recognized fact that historically as well as presently, such actions are taken in the best interests of the countries involved.” Transcript of President’s News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters, N.Y. TIMES, Sept. 17, 1974; see also Richard A. Falk, MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW103 rejected such attempts at justifying interventions in other states' affairs. Responding to arguments put forward by the United States in order to justify its support of the Contra rebels in Nicaragua, the ICJ declared: It [the Court] has to consider whether there might be indications of a practice illustrative of belief in a kind of general right for States to intervene, directly or indirectly, with or without armed force, in support of an internal opposition in another State, whose cause appeared particularly worthy by reason of the political and moral values with which it was identified. For such a general right to come into existence would involve a fundamental modification of the customary law principle of non-intervention[233]. . . The Court therefore finds that no such general right of intervention, in support of an opposition within another State, exists in contemporary international law.[234] ## Economic Measures Nevertheless, one of the most coercive interventions in another state's electoral process remains lawful.         "236": "See Damrosch, supra note 11, at 29–30; Watts, supra note 10, at 12–13; but see Helal, supra note 10, at 7, 62–64, 81–84, 85–86. In Helal’s view, withdrawing or granting benefits in order to achieve a specific election result –though generally lawful– becomes unlawful, if such actions are combined with other unlawful means. He views such a strategy as a composite breach of the non-intervention rule. Less convincingly, he argues that such economic measures merely amount to “persuasion” if not combined with unlawful means. Helal, supra note 10, at 81. For example, Helal views the hacking of the emails circulating among the leadership of Democratic Party and their subsequent publication in order to influence the 2016 U.S. presidential election as unlawful. Had Russia at the same time threatened to impose sanctions on the United States, these sanctions would have therefore been rendered unlawful. Had Russia, on the other hand, only threatened the United States with the imposition of sanctions in the case of a Clinton victory, that, in his view, would have been lawful. A potentially extremely coercive measure’s legality (imposition of sanctions) would thus depend on whether the intervenor resorted to other, potentially minor, but unlawful means of intervention, which is not convincing. See also Declaration on the Inadmissibility of Intervention on the Internal Affairs of States, UN GA Res. 36/103 (1981), op. para. II (k).         "239": "See Nicar. v. U.S., 1986 I.C.J. 14, ¶ 205. MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW105 consequences or the promise of economic benefits, as well as the intervening state's conduct, are arguably facts that voters should be considering when casting their vote. ## Summary A state is free to interfere during another state's election campaign as long as its intent is persuasive rather than coercive. Issuing statements in support of one of the competing parties, instigating editorials in domestic newspapers, or broadcasting reports supportive of a candidate are lawful. The target state can respond, and the electorate can evaluate such information correctly. It is also lawful to disseminate true information in a timely manner so long as the intervenor obtained it in a lawful fashion. Once a state resorts to deceit and manipulation in order to disguise its intentions, the intervention becomes unlawful, as the target state cannot terminate the interference. The intervening state is thereby actively, but often covertly, participating in the target state's election campaign in such a way that the intervenor hopes the target state cannot prevent or terminate. Funding foreign political parties or intervening in the electoral process itself is similarly coercive in nature and violates the prohibition on interventions. Nevertheless, any prospective intervenor has a powerful tool at its disposal—although also clearly coercive, the threat to sever, or the promise to enhance, economic relations is lawful, as such decisions are at every state's, the intervenor's included, discretion. ## A brief legal analysis of the interventions in 1948 and 2016 Applied to the 1948 election in Italy and the 2016 election in the United States, the foregoing analysis leads to the following assessment: official statements on the part of US officials in the run-up to the Italian election in 1948, which statements advised against voting for the Communist Party, were lawful, as their aim was to persuade rather than coerce. Similarly, the broadcasts, such as those by the Voice of America, described above (which broadcasts were accessible in Italy) or through Russian-origin television programs on RT or Sputnik, even though biased and perhaps influential, were not unlawful either. Similarly, the intent of the massive letter-writing campaign organized in the United States among Italian Americans was persuasive rather than coercive. The forging of documents, the bribing of Italian journalists, and the massive funding of center-right parties in Italy were unlawful, as were INDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2 the efforts by the Russian government to initiate and maintain a social media campaign in favor of Trump utilizing fake American identities. The hacking of e-mails originating from leaders within Clinton's Democratic Party, and the subsequent disclosure of the information, were unlawful because they were gained by unlawful espionage in order to achieve an unlawful aim—namely, having a say in another state's election outcome. Without more details, it is difficult to judge whether the US disclosures as far as Italian politicians' personal lives are concerned were lawful or unlawful—that depends on how the information was obtained and whether the stories disseminated were true or false. Lastly, possibly the most coercive instruments used by the United States, the threat to stop economic aid to Italy and the promise of further economic support dependent on the Italian election results, were lawful, as was the threat to bar Communist-supporting Italians from entering the United States, because these measures were within the United States' rights as an independent state conducting its external affairs. ## THE VIOLATION OF SOVEREIGNTY Intervening in another state's election can also imply a violation of that state's sovereignty. MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW109 Similarly, the manipulation of voting machines located on the target state's territory, whether remotely or not, will violate the target state's sovereignty, as the target state's governmental authority is being usurped.²⁵⁵ Some forms of cyber activity, such as the hacking of e-mails stored on servers located within the target state's territory, will also involve an unlawful disregard of that state's sovereignty.²⁵⁶ Nevertheless, basing the unlawfulness of election meddling solely on the violation of the target state's sovereignty has significant drawbacks, as many of the interventions described above would consequently be lawful.²⁵⁷ If a state funds a foreign political party or candidate with the potential effect of massively influencing the outcome of the target state's election, there are many possible scenarios that do not involve a violation of the target state's sovereignty.²⁵⁸ Basically, it would be sufficient to hand over any monies on the intervenor's territory to avoid any violation of international law. Similarly, many of the cyber activities mentioned above, such as posting political messages under the guise of being a target-state citizen, cannot plausibly be argued to violate the target state's sovereignty so long as the activity is conducted from outside the target state's territory.²⁵⁹ Also, some forms of cyber espionage do not violate the target state's sovereignty, such as intercepting e-mails during transmission or obtaining e-mails stored on servers located outside of the target state's territory.²⁶⁰ In summary, although the violation of the target state's sovereignty is often implicated when discussing election meddling, there are many instances of such behavior that cannot be construed as interfering with the target state's exclusive authority within its territory.²⁶¹ Furthermore, the reliance on a sovereignty violation also does not address the one issue the prohibition on interventions does not resolve: threatening economic consequences in the case of an unfavorable election outcome does not violate the target state's sovereignty but is rather an expression of the intervenor's sovereignty. INDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2 discussion of election meddling than the prohibition on interventions in the internal matters of other states. ## THE RIGHT OF SELF-DETERMINATION More recently, Jens David Ohlin has suggested another line of argument. According to him, election meddling, such as the actions the Russians are accused of in relation to the 2016 US presidential election, violates the collective right of self-determination of the target state's people.²⁶² By implication, Ohlin suggests that the prohibition of such actions may be limited to cases where the states targeted are democracies.²⁶³ This line of reasoning is not convincing for a number of reasons. Most scholars responding to Ohlin's arguments have pointed out that the right of self-determination has so far not been viewed as applicable to already existent states.²⁶⁴ Rather, the counterargument goes, the right of self-determination has traditionally only been granted to peoples in the process of decolonization.²⁶⁵ More recently, in light of the Canadian Supreme Court's groundbreaking judgment on a possible secession by Québec,²⁶⁶ some have argued that a right of external self-determination could apply to a people suffering internal discrimination within an existent state.²⁶⁷ Sovereign states though, the argument concludes, cannot lay claim to a right of self-determination.²⁶⁸ Although the arguments just set out do have some merit, I agree with Ohlin that a people living within an already existent state does have a right of self-determination that can be violated.²⁶⁹ There is no reason to believe that the right of self-determination automatically ceases to exist once a people has managed to organize itself in an",

MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW111 independent state.²⁷⁰ However, that right of self-determination of a people in an existent state is already protected by the prohibition on interventions.²⁷¹ The prohibition on coercive interventions in matters that each state can decide freely also serves to protect that state's people's right of self-determination.²⁷² As the ICJ has explained, an intervention is unlawful when it bears on matters such as \"the choice of a political, economic, social and cultural system, and the formulation of foreign policy.\"²⁷³ As James Crawford has explained, \"Where a self-determination unit is a State, the principle of self-determination is represented by the rule against intervention in the internal affairs of that State, and in particular in the choice of the form of government of the State.\"²⁷⁴ Thus, prohibited interventions are interventions that (also) violate the target-state people's right of self-determination.²⁷⁵ Furthermore, Ohlin's arguments have little prospect of acceptance as a rule of customary international law due to their implied reliance on the target state's \"democratic\" structures. Ohlin does not explore what the term \"democracy\" means in public international law. Is a state a democracy simply because there are competing parties and voters are permitted to cast ballots?²⁷⁶ Developments in states such as Iraq, Libya,",

        "271": "CRAWFORD, supra note 269, at 128; Tsagourias, supra note 7, at 1, 4, 12–14; Lobel, supra note 76, at 9; Helal, supra note 10, at 53; Meyer, supra note 76, at 99; see Falk, supra note 232, at 357–58; Jackamo, supra note 76, at 964–65; Damrosch, supra note 11, at 37; see also G.A. Res. 2734 (XXV) ¶ 4, Declaration on International Security (Dec. 16, 1970). But see Ohlen, supra note 10, at 67–89 (viewing the prohibition on interventions as protecting only a state's sovereignty). However, Ohlen's proposition is not convincing. A state's sovereignty is not necessarily completely identical to the right to be free from outside interventions as Ohlen claims. Rather, sovereignty and the prohibition on interventions certainly overlap insofar as the intervenor is interfering with the target state's right to govern within its territory. However, a prohibited intervention can take place that, for example, aims to severely disrupt the target state's foreign or trade policy. Such an intervention would not necessarily violate the target state's sovereignty, as it does not need to take place on its territory and does not have to amount to a usurpation of the target state's governmental functions within that territory. Thus, violating another state's sovereignty and intervening in its domain réservé are both unlawful, but at times distinct offenses. See also Van de Velde, supra note 10, at 15.",

She only wants to exclude target states from the prohibition of interventions that evidence a “serious pattern of violation of political human rights,” while emphasizing that “[w]estern-style pluralist democracy is only one of a variety of models that states may employ to give their citizens a voice in government . . .” Limiting international law’s protection to “democratic” states, on the other hand, may well lead to a “disagreement . . . over the specific modalities of political participation. In summary, there is no need to rely on a right of self-determination as far as existent states are concerned, as their peoples' right of self-determination is sufficiently protected by the prohibition on interventions in the internal affairs of other states. Furthermore, the way Ohlin seems to want to apply such a right—namely, by offering protection only to democratic systems as understood mainly in the United States—has no chance of being accepted as a rule of customary international law, as non-Western states are bound to reject the creation of a rule that gives the impression of being self-serving. ## CONCLUSION This article set out to examine the lawfulness of foreign election meddling in public international law. I began by describing two such events in the past in more detail—the US interference in the Italian election of 1948 and the Russian activities in relation to the US election in 2016. I then briefly addressed a few other instances of US or Russian election interference. These examples served to illustrate that it has always been possible to become heavily involved in other states' elections and that states have done so in different ways. Past US interference in other states' elections may help explain US President Obama's ambiguous statement regarding Russian election meddling in 2016, when he declared such actions as Russian \"efforts to undermine international norms of behavior.\"²⁸⁷ Subsequently, I analyzed whether such election meddling is compatible with public international law and argued that the prohibition on interventions in other states' internal affairs is the decisive rule of international law when trying to establish whether a specific action amounts to a violation of international law. There is widespread agreement that elections are among the matters protected by the prohibition on interventions.²⁸⁸ The subsequent analysis therefore centered on the question of whether specific actions",

MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW115 can be classified as “methods of coercion.” The term “coercion” obviously excludes from the prohibition means of persuasion.²⁸⁹ Therefore, it is, for example, not unlawful for a state to publicly state its preferences as to the outcome of an election in another state.²⁹⁰ The interfering state is thereby simply advocating an outcome that it believes to be in its national interest. The target state and its people remain free to decide whether and how to respond. Such persuasion, however, morphs into coercion if the intervenor employs deception or manipulation in order to promote its self-interest during another state’s election campaign.²⁹¹ Although messages posted on social media may be persuasive rather than coercive in content, the fact that the intervenor disguises these posts’ origin by implying that they reflect views held by target-state citizens makes them coercive, as the target state cannot respond to, much less terminate, such interference at its pleasure. It is the target state’s helplessness in the face of such interference that is the driving force behind the intervenor’s deception. The intervening state actively participates in another state’s election campaign in a way that the target cannot respond to, much less prevent or terminate. This therefore amounts to coercive interference. It follows that more intrusive election meddling, such as spreading fake news, (cyber) espionage, and funding political parties and individual politicians, as well as disrupting the target state’s electoral process, certainly meet the threshold of a prohibited intervention.²⁹² This threshold is even more clearly met if the intervenor’s goal is to undermine the public’s trust in the target state’s electoral process.²⁹³ However, the analysis also revealed that one of the most coercive interventions in another state’s election is lawful. The threat to sever economic ties or, conversely, the promise of economic benefits dependent on the election result is potentially extremely coercive as far as voters",

Given that maintaining, enhancing, or discontinuing economic ties with another state is widely seen as an issue at every state's sovereign discretion, it follows that such economic coercion, nevertheless, remains lawful.²⁹⁴ In such instances, it could even plausibly be argued that the intervenor is providing target-state citizens with information they may wish to consider when deciding who to vote for. Lastly, the application of these rules to the instances of election meddling in Italy in 1948 and the United States in 2016 confirms that the prohibition on interventions enables a comprehensive legal analysis of foreign interference in elections. After explaining the central role of the prohibition on interventions when judging the lawfulness of election meddling, I briefly set out why I believe the two other rules of international law that are invoked in this context are less satisfactory. While many of the activities associated with election meddling potentially violate the target state's sovereignty, I also explained that many other such undertakings do not. Funding political parties, and many forms of cyber intervention, often do not undermine the target state's exclusive authority within its territory.²⁹⁵ Lastly, I discussed the right of self-determination as another potential rule of public international law implicated by election meddling, as is argued by Jens Ohlin.²⁹⁶ I argued that, in my view, there is no room for the separate application of the right of self-determination as far as already existent states are concerned, as their peoples' rights are sufficiently protected by the prohibition of outside interventions in their internal matters.²⁹⁷ Furthermore, Jens Ohlin, at least by implication, ²⁹⁴. It follows that there is no chance of such a rule being accepted as customary international law by a majority of states. Many forms of election meddling are unlawful and violate the prohibition on interventions in other states' internal affairs. The fact that economic coercion remains lawful, however, renders the prohibition much less effective. Of course, it would be beneficial if clear international rules could be developed that outline which conduct is permissible in respect of other states' elections. Now that powerful states such as the United States are themselves vulnerable to potentially decisive foreign election meddling, there may even be a unique opportunity to develop such legal guidelines. That kind of discussion is urgently needed, as the danger of massive interventions in foreign elections is growing rapidly due to the vast possibilities the internet offers. However, it is also true that many of the actions described previously do not violate another state's sovereignty so that many of the intervenor's actions would be left unregulated. More recently, Jens Ohlin has suggested that election meddling violates the target-state population's collective right of self-determination.[13] I will briefly set out why I believe this to be unconvincing based on the fact that, in my view, the collective right of self-determination of peoples in already existent states is one of the rights the prohibition on interventions protects. In this article, I will not deal with the issue of attribution of election meddling to states, which, certainly in the cyber realm, has at times become an almost insoluble problem. Furthermore, I will not discuss whether a state has the duty to stop private individuals from intervening in another state's elections. When actions of private individuals or companies are mentioned in this article, it will be assumed that the respective state instructed such private actors to undertake the intrusive actions described. Finally, as far as specific actions are attributed to specific states, I am relying on publicly available information. Obviously, I cannot judge whether the conclusions drawn as to a state's responsibility are correct. ## ELECTION MEDDLING IN 1948 AND 2016 AND FURTHER EXAMPLES Russia's 2016 operation was simply the cyber-age version of standard United States practice for decades, whenever American officials were worried about a foreign vote.[14] In this section, I will analyze two well-known examples of election meddling before summarizing some other instances of alleged US and Russian election interference. First, I will describe the US intervention in the Italian parliamentary election of 1948 before subsequently outlining Russian activities in the run-up to the US presidential election of 2016. This short chapter aims to show the various methods states employ in order to influence the outcome of elections in other states. This comparison will also serve to refute the argument that, due to the internet, the scope of election meddling has become much greater. Following a coup and the eruption of civil war in the country, El Salvador held elections in 1982. According to one account, the United States \"planned, organised, funded, managed, and publicized\" the election in order to win international support for its policy of supporting right-leaning politicians in the country, while the state's government merely \"acquiesc[ed]\" to the US demand for an election.[76] Due to the conditions the incumbent government imposed as far as the election was concerned, leftist parties did not participate. In the election of that year, the incumbent government composed of the Sandinistas faced off against Violetta Chamorro, a conservative candidate.           "footnote": "See Nicholas Tsagourias, Electoral Cyber Interference, Self-Determination and the Principle of Non-Intervention in Cyberspace, WHITE ROSE RESEARCH ONLINE 1, 3-4, 12 (2019), http://eprints.whiterose.ac.uk/159652/. MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW71 In order to illustrate that election meddling is a long-standing practice and that past instances evidenced interference on a massive scale, I will first describe two well-known examples of outside interference in more detail—the massive US intervention in the Italian election of 1948 and the Russian interference in the US elections in 2016—before briefly turning to some other instances of alleged US and Russian election meddling. This will be followed by an in-depth analysis of the legality of foreign election meddling, which will conclude that the prohibition on interventions in the internal affairs of other states is the appropriate benchmark to decide whether a specific action by a state to interfere in another state's election was lawful or not.⁸ The analysis will necessitate a definition of what constitutes a prohibited intervention in the internal affairs of another state. Based on the partial definition the International Court of Justice (ICJ) provided,⁹ it needs to be established, firstly, whether the intervenor's aim was to influence matters that belong to the target state's protected internal affairs (domaine réservé). There is, however, widespread agreement that the process whereby a population chooses its government falls within the scope of the matters protected by the prohibition on interventions.¹⁰ ⁸. See Steven Wheatley, Foreign Interference in Elections under the Non-Intervention Principle: We Need to Talk About \"Coercion\", 31 DUKE J. COMPAR. &amp; INT'L L. 161–62, 173, 176 (2020). ⁹. Helal, On Coercion in International Law, 52 INT'L L. &amp; POL. 1, 65–67 (2019); Steven J. INT'L L.J. 183, 199 (2019); JENS DAVID OHLIN, ELECTION INTERFERENCE: INTERNATIONAL LAW AND THE FUTURE OF DEMOCRACY 83–84 (2020); Snezana Trifunovska, The Principle of Non-Interference and Cyber Operations, 2017 HUNGARIAN Y.B. Hollis eds., 2021); Wheatley, supra note 8, at 174; Sean Watts, Low-Intensity Cyber Operations and the Principle of Non-Intervention, 14 BALTIC Y.B. L.J. 31, 40 (2018) (stating how recent cases of intervention do not have evidence of coercion and thus prohibitions on intervention cannot prevent them); Stephen Townley, Intervention's Idiosyncrasies: The Need for a New Approach to Understanding Sub-Forcible Intervention, 42 FORDHAM INT'L L.J. 1167, 1190–93 (2019) (discussing the INDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2 Secondly, for the intervention to be unlawful, it needs to be coercive. At what point mere interference morphs into a coercive intervention is very controversial. I will argue that, generally speaking, interference turns coercive when the target state cannot terminate the outside meddling at its pleasure. By differentiating lawful interference from possibly unlawful intervention, it will become obvious that states do have some leeway in trying to influence another state's voters. Even if this is irritating to the target state, it is, for example, acceptable for a foreign government to express its preferences as to who ought to win an election in another state so that official criticism of a foreign party's manifesto, or of statements made by foreign politicians, is similarly lawful. If, at the other end of the scale, the intervenor attempts to attack another state's election procedure by manipulating vote counts, deleting or adding voters to electoral registers, or otherwise disrupting the electoral process, then the threshold of a coercive intervention is undoubtedly met. In my view, the same is true when a state engages in funding preferred parties or candidates in another state. But the threshold of intervention is also met, I will argue, when actions that may well only be judged as persuasive if clearly attributable to a foreign state are instead undertaken in a deceptive, manipulative way. For example, when a state pays off target-state journalists so that they write or broadcast comment pieces favorable to the intervenor's goals during an election campaign or initiates a campaign on social media, and thereby insinuates that the relevant posts were authored by target-state citizens, then that constitutes unlawful intervention. This is even more the case if the intervenor spreads fake news or engages in espionage to obtain information harmful to the disfavored candidate that is then published during an election campaign. In these borderline cases, the difference between persuasion and intervention comes down to the deception. If a state openly articulates its preferences, the target state can react in all kinds of ways, and its citizens can evaluate the foreign state's statements in the proper context. The manipulative intrusion, on the other hand, robs the target state of the opportunity to react and serves to confuse the electorate that, for example, may well judge a fellow citizen's views differently than it would a foreign state's opinion. This difference is also the reason for the deception on the part of the intervenor. The intervening state does not want to be recognized as such, well aware that its views otherwise might well be dismissed by target-state voters and refuted by the target state itself. By posturing as a target-state citizen or complexities of domaine réservé and when it allows the prohibition of intervention). MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW73 organization, the intervenor wants to prevent the target state from reacting, as there is no reason why a state should prohibit its citizens from expressing their views. The intervening state's conduct thus amounts to coercion because it actively participates in another state's election campaign in a way the target state cannot prevent or terminate. Furthermore, the intervening state cannot rely on any legal justification for its actions. Such actions are therefore unlawful interventions in the internal affairs of another state, whether successful or not. My analysis of prohibited interventions will, however, also make the point that it is not always sufficient for an act to be coercive to be unlawful. Exceptionally, even a coercive intervention can be lawful if the means employed by the intervening state correspond with its sovereign right to decide its own external matters freely. For example, a state may threaten to impose economic sanctions on another state if a specific party is elected into power. Although frequently more coercive in effect than manipulating and deceiving voters during an election campaign, such a threat, nevertheless, is lawful, as there is still widespread agreement that it is at every state's discretion to decide the states it wants to do business with.[11] Furthermore, it is at least arguable that by announcing such measures before an election, the intervenor is providing target-state voters with factual information they may wish to consider when casting their vote. Before concluding, I will briefly analyze other rules of public international law that may be implicated by election meddling and explain why I believe these rules are not as relevant to the discussion as the prohibition on interventions.       "flat_text": "# Voting by Proxy—Meddling in Foreign Elections and Public International Law\nPATRICK C. R. TERRY*\nIn the midst of these pleasing ideas we should be unfaithful to ourselves if we should ever lose sight of the danger to our liberties if anything partial or extraneous should infect the purity of our free, fair, virtuous, and independent elections. . . . If that solitary suffrage can be obtained by foreign nations by flattery or menaces, by fraud or violence, by terror, intrigue, or venality, the Government may not be the choice of the American people, but of foreign nations. It may be foreign nations who govern us, and not we, the people, who govern ourselves. . . .¹\nFollowing the alleged Russian meddling in the 2016 US presidential election, there has been noticeable interest in the lawfulness of foreign interference in another state's elections under public international law. The obvious lack of previous research on the issue is surprising, given that election meddling in other states has been a widespread practice since at least the end of World War II.² Indeed, according to Dov Levin, between 1946 and 2000, the United States and the Soviet Union (and Russia) alone were responsible for 117 partisan “electoral interventions”\n* Patrick C. R. Terry is the Dean of the Faculty of Law and a Professor of Law at the University of Public Administration in Kehl (Germany). The author would like to thank the editorial staff at IJGLS for their helpful suggestions.\n\nIndiana Journal of Global Legal Studies Vol. 29 #2 © Indiana University Maurer School of Law INDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2 in other states.³ What is more, meddling in foreign elections is effective. Based on his groundbreaking research on foreign interference in elections,⁴ Dov Levin has concluded, “I find such interference to have a significant impact in the desired direction in most situations, frequently in a magnitude sufficient to determine the identity of the winner.”⁵ Why, then, this sudden interest in the topic? Most likely, this is due to the fact that, for the first time in ages, the United States was the target of a meaningful information operation initiated abroad, with the goal of influencing the outcome of a presidential election.⁶ However, many instead have argued that new means of technology have made it necessary to analyze the legal situation in more detail—the way social media enables foreign governments to target an audience of millions by spreading fake or manipulated news stories.⁷ While there can be no doubt that the internet has changed the dimensions of what is possible as far as spreading propaganda or misinformation is concerned, it is, nevertheless, not correct to claim that the election meddling of the past was much less intrusive. Rather, considering the contemporary means at the disposal of both the target states and the foreign intervenors, past election meddling has at times been comparable, if not more intrusive, than the Russian actions in the run-up to the 2016 election in the United States. Rather than limiting the discussion to cyber meddling, it is therefore justified to examine the lawfulness of election meddling as a whole, irrespective of the technical means employed.\n\nMEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW71 In order to illustrate that election meddling is a long-standing practice and that past instances evidenced interference on a massive scale, I will first describe two well-known examples of outside interference in more detail—the massive US intervention in the Italian election of 1948 and the Russian interference in the US elections in 2016—before briefly turning to some other instances of alleged US and Russian election meddling. This will be followed by an in-depth analysis of the legality of foreign election meddling, which will conclude that the prohibition on interventions in the internal affairs of other states is the appropriate benchmark to decide whether a specific action by a state to interfere in another state's election was lawful or not.⁸ The analysis will necessitate a definition of what constitutes a prohibited intervention in the internal affairs of another state. Based on the partial definition the International Court of Justice (ICJ) provided,⁹ it needs to be established, firstly, whether the intervenor's aim was to influence matters that belong to the target state's protected internal affairs (domaine réservé). There is, however, widespread agreement that the process whereby a population chooses its government falls within the scope of the matters protected by the prohibition on interventions.¹⁰ ⁸. At what point mere interference morphs into a coercive intervention is very controversial. I will argue that, generally speaking, interference turns coercive when the target state cannot terminate the outside meddling at its pleasure. By differentiating lawful interference from possibly unlawful intervention, it will become obvious that states do have some leeway in trying to influence another state's voters. Even if this is irritating to the target state, it is, for example, acceptable for a foreign government to express its preferences as to who ought to win an election in another state so that official criticism of a foreign party's manifesto, or of statements made by foreign politicians, is similarly lawful. If, at the other end of the scale, the intervenor attempts to attack another state's election procedure by manipulating vote counts, deleting or adding voters to electoral registers, or otherwise disrupting the electoral process, then the threshold of a coercive intervention is undoubtedly met. In my view, the same is true when a state engages in funding preferred parties or candidates in another state.\nBut the threshold of intervention is also met, I will argue, when actions that may well only be judged as persuasive if clearly attributable to a foreign state are instead undertaken in a deceptive, manipulative way. For example, when a state pays off target-state journalists so that they write or broadcast comment pieces favorable to the intervenor's goals during an election campaign or initiates a campaign on social media, and thereby insinuates that the relevant posts were authored by target-state citizens, then that constitutes unlawful intervention. This is even more the case if the intervenor spreads fake news or engages in espionage to obtain information harmful to the disfavored candidate that is then published during an election campaign.\nIn these borderline cases, the difference between persuasion and intervention comes down to the deception. If a state openly articulates its preferences, the target state can react in all kinds of ways, and its citizens can evaluate the foreign state's statements in the proper context. The manipulative intrusion, on the other hand, robs the target state of the opportunity to react and serves to confuse the electorate that, for example, may well judge a fellow citizen's views differently than it would a foreign state's opinion. This difference is also the reason for the deception on the part of the intervenor. The intervening state does not want to be recognized as such, well aware that its views otherwise might well be dismissed by target-state voters and refuted by the target state itself. By posturing as a target-state citizen or complexities of domaine réservé and when it allows the prohibition of intervention).\nMEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW73 organization, the intervenor wants to prevent the target state from reacting, as there is no reason why a state should prohibit its citizens from expressing their views. The intervening state's conduct thus amounts to coercion because it actively participates in another state's election campaign in a way the target state cannot prevent or terminate. Furthermore, the intervening state cannot rely on any legal justification for its actions. Such actions are therefore unlawful interventions in the internal affairs of another state, whether successful or not.\nMy analysis of prohibited interventions will, however, also make the point that it is not always sufficient for an act to be coercive to be unlawful. Exceptionally, even a coercive intervention can be lawful if the means employed by the intervening state correspond with its sovereign right to decide its own external matters freely. For example, a state may threaten to impose economic sanctions on another state if a specific party is elected into power. Although frequently more coercive in effect than manipulating and deceiving voters during an election campaign, such a threat, nevertheless, is lawful, as there is still widespread agreement that it is at every state's discretion to decide the states it wants to do business with.[11] Furthermore, it is at least arguable that by announcing such measures before an election, the intervenor is providing target-state voters with factual information they may wish to consider when casting their vote.\nBefore concluding, I will briefly analyze other rules of public international law that may be implicated by election meddling and explain why I believe these rules are not as relevant to the discussion as the prohibition on interventions. Many authors argue that election meddling violates the target state's sovereignty.[12] And indeed, very often INDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2 election meddling will also result in a violation of another state's sovereignty. However, it is also true that many of the actions described previously do not violate another state's sovereignty so that many of the intervenor's actions would be left unregulated. More recently, Jens Ohlin has suggested that election meddling violates the target-state population's collective right of self-determination.[13] I will briefly set out why I believe this to be unconvincing based on the fact that, in my view, the collective right of self-determination of peoples in already existent states is one of the rights the prohibition on interventions protects.\nIn this article, I will not deal with the issue of attribution of election meddling to states, which, certainly in the cyber realm, has at times become an almost insoluble problem. Furthermore, I will not discuss whether a state has the duty to stop private individuals from intervening in another state's elections. When actions of private individuals or companies are mentioned in this article, it will be assumed that the respective state instructed such private actors to undertake the intrusive actions described. Finally, as far as specific actions are attributed to specific states, I am relying on publicly available information. Obviously, I cannot judge whether the conclusions drawn as to a state's responsibility are correct.\n## ELECTION MEDDLING IN 1948 AND 2016 AND FURTHER EXAMPLES Russia's 2016 operation was simply the cyber-age version of standard United States practice for decades, whenever American officials were worried about a foreign vote.[14] In this section, I will analyze two well-known examples of election meddling before summarizing some other instances of alleged US and Russian election interference. First, I will describe the US intervention in the Italian parliamentary election of 1948 before subsequently outlining Russian activities in the run-up to the US presidential election of 2016. This short chapter aims to show the various methods states employ in order to influence the outcome of elections in other states. This comparison will also serve to refute the argument that, due to the internet, the scope of election meddling has become much greater. Although the US intervention in the Italian election occurred almost seventy years before the Russians meddled in the US election, it is the MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW75 former intervention that was more intrusive and likely more successful.\n## US intervention in the Italian election of 1948 The Italian parliamentary election of 1948 was an early milestone in foreign election meddling. In the United States and elsewhere, there were fears that the Communist Party might win the forthcoming elections and be able to form a government.[15] This was seen as a potential major setback in the struggle against Soviet advances in Europe.[16] As a result, there was massive US intervention in the run-up to the election in support of the center-right parties, mainly the Christian Democrats, by means of overt economic aid and military support, as well as covert operations.[17] To that end, the United States engaged in massive funding of these parties.[18] Between 1948 and 1968, $65 million was spent on supporting center-right parties and individual politicians in Italy.[19] The estimate of the amount spent by the United States on the 1948 election[20] varies between $1 million[21] and $10 INDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2 million.²² Such generosity enabled the anti-Communist parties to spend 7.5 times more on the election campaign than the Communists.²³ This generosity was accompanied by a massive propaganda campaign that highlighted Soviet activities in Eastern Europe.²⁴ Pamphlets were produced that targeted Communist politicians' personal lives.²⁵ Letters allegedly from members of the Communist Party were forged and published widely.²⁶ Voice of America regularly broadcast US propaganda, as did various commercial radio stations with the support of the US State Department.²⁷ A massive letter-writing campaign was organized whereby Americans of Italian extraction were encouraged to write to their relatives in Italy to discourage them from voting for the Communists. At first written by Italian Americans themselves, these letters were soon mass-produced and only required an address and a signature.²⁸ Around ten million of such letters were sent to Italy.²⁹ On the other hand, the United States publicly threatened to reduce or stop any economic assistance should the Communists be elected, while promising to increase such aid in the event of the emergence of a government excluding the Communist Party.³⁰ Furthermore, the United States threatened to bar all Italians who were members of the Communist Party from entering the United States.³¹ There was some British assistance in support of US election interference.³² In the British Embassy in Rome, a committee was formed to organize covert election meddling.³³ To guarantee more favorable https://www.dollartimes.com/inflation/inflation.php?amount=1&amp;year=1948 (last visited Jan. 29, 2022) (calculating that $1 in 1948 equals around $11.13 in 2021).\n\nMEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW77 reporting in Italian newspapers, journalists were bribed.³⁴ Unattributable papers were distributed to influence the electorate.³⁵ The greatest British triumph probably was the creation of the popular Don Camillo and Peppone series about a Communist mayor and a Catholic priest.³⁶ Nevertheless, due to financial restraints, the British effort was minor in comparison to US involvement.³⁷ US intervention in Italy might have become much more far-reaching had the Communists won the election. In some circles within the US government, there were debates on whether to intervene militarily or support a coup carried out by Italian military forces should the Communist Party emerge victorious from the elections.³⁸ In the end, the party supported by the United States, the Christian Democrats, won the 1948 parliamentary elections.³⁹ This was mainly or at least partly due, many believe, to the United States' massive involvement in the election campaign.⁴⁰ ## Russian intervention in the U.S. election of 2016 In early 2016, the Russian government and figures associated with the Russian government began to prepare their campaign of interference in the 2016 presidential election in the United States. The aim of Russian meddling was to help defeat the Democratic Party candidate, the former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton—who was perceived as being very critical of the Russian government—and to support the election of the Republican Party candidate, Donald Trump.⁴¹ INDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2 According to US authorities, Russia also sought to sow discord among Americans⁴² and to generally undermine public trust in the US electoral process and system of government.⁴³ To achieve this, the Russia-based Internet Research Agency (IRA), which according to the US government was “tasked” to do this by the Russian government,⁴⁴ bought advertisements supportive of Trump, or his policies, on social media sites, such as Facebook.⁴⁵ Moreover, in order to achieve its goal, fictitious Facebook,⁴⁶ Instagram,⁴⁷ and Twitter accounts were created.⁴⁸ Overall, the IRA was responsible for more than 61,500 posts on Facebook, more than 116,000 posts on Instagram, and more than 10.4 million tweets on Twitter.⁴⁹ In all of these instances, the IRA’s authorship was not acknowledged. Rather, the aim was to create the impression that these were messages posted by US citizens.⁵⁰ According to one estimate, the Russian-inspired Facebook posts reached 126 million users.⁵¹ Many of these posts were also successful in instigating actual US citizens to take further action, such as forwarding the posts to acquaintances.⁵² The IRA also used its social media presence to promote Trump rallies.⁵³ In addition, Russian news sites and television channels, such as RT and Sputnik, regularly broadcast material that was supportive of Trump and critical of Clinton.⁵⁴ Furthermore, Russia initiated the hacking of email accounts of persons in the Democratic Party leadership who were associated with Hillary Clinton.⁵⁵ These emails, which were damaging to the Clinton campaign, were subsequently published by WikiLeaks, allegedly in note 10, at 186.\n\nMEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW79 cooperation with Russian government circles.56 As is well known, the candidate the Russian government supported, Donald Trump, was victorious in the 2016 presidential election. In his research on election meddling, Dov Levin concluded that Russian interference may well have been decisive in securing that outcome.57 ## Further Examples As these two examples illustrate, states have been intervening in other states' elections for a long time. It is also not necessarily true that the possibilities of the internet have enabled states to intervene much more forcefully. The Italian example illustrates that it has always been possible to massively interfere in the electoral process of another state.\nThere have been many other examples that evidence this as well, such as US meddling in Latin America during the Cold War. Here, too, the US government sought to prevent the election of governments perceived as communist or socialist. Probably the most notorious US campaign in that respect took place in Chile. Beginning in the early 1960s, the United States became actively involved during election campaigns there. Following a coup and the eruption of civil war in the country, El Salvador held elections in 1982. In the election of that year, the incumbent government composed of the Sandinistas faced off against Violetta Chamorro, a conservative candidate. The United States had for many years supported the Contra rebels against the Sandinista government and wanted to ensure that movement's defeat in the upcoming elections.[80] During the election campaign, the United States spent $5 million on supporting parties within the opposition alliance.[81] US President George Bush Sr. and many members of Congress publicly endorsed the opposition candidate, and the US government declared that the trade embargo would be lifted if Chamorro won.[82] Furthermore, the CIA\"leaked damaging information\"claiming that the incumbent government was corrupt.[83] Role of the United States in El Salvador, 7 ASILS INT'L L.J. 89 (1983) (detailing the U.S.'s involvement in El Salvador's election from 1981 to 1983).\n\nINDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2 The United States' preferred candidate won.\nMore recently, the United States has been accused of interfering in Russia's presidential election of 1996⁸⁴ and the parliamentary election of 2011.⁸⁵ Dov Levin has described US interference in Russia's 1996 presidential election in favor of Boris Yeltsin as\"one of the most massive electoral interventions recorded in [his] dataset,\"⁸⁶ which covers the period from 1946 to 2000. The US government seemed to believe that the deeply unpopular Yeltsin⁸⁷ was the only democratic candidate and that it was necessary to prevent the victory of the Communist Party candidate.⁸⁸ In a highly critical report, the Speaker's Special Advisory Group on Russia concluded in 2000 that the US government had\"pressur[ed]\"the International Monetary Fund (IMF)\"to grant $10.2 billion in credits to Russia\"and had thereby\"effectively used the Fund... to subsidize Boris Yeltsin's reelection campaign.\"⁸⁹ Furthermore, US spin-doctors flew into Moscow to support Boris Yeltsin's campaign.⁹⁰ According to some reports, their work was decisive in securing his eventual victory.⁹¹ How closely these advisors were connected to the US government remains unclear.⁹² During the 2011 parliamentary election campaign, the Russian government accused the US of interference in order to undermine MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW83 Russia's then-Prime Minister Vladimir Putin. Allegedly, the US government paid NGOs in Russia to discredit the Russian electoral process even before the election had taken place.⁹³ Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin condemned such activities and declared:\"When financing comes to some domestic organizations which are supposedly national, but which in fact work on foreign money and perform to the music of a foreign state during electoral processes, we need to safeguard ourselves from this interference in our internal affairs and defend our sovereignty.\"⁹⁴ Vladimir Putin subsequently also accused the United States of instigating the protests that erupted following the elections, during which claims of electoral fraud were made.⁹⁵ Past US activities therefore may help explain US President Barack Obama's ambiguous statement regarding Russian election meddling in 2016, when he declared such actions Russian\"efforts to undermine international norms of behavior.\"⁹⁶ Although the statement fell short of an explicit condemnation of Russia's conduct as unlawful,⁹⁷ it does at the same time also leave some room for interpreting the US stance in such a way.⁹⁸ Russia, too, has been accused of meddling in other states' elections on numerous other occasions—for example, in the UK's Brexit referendum in 2016⁹⁹ and its general election in 2019.¹⁰⁰ While the pro-Brexit UK government has so far refused to investigate claims that Russia interfered during the 2016 Brexit referendum campaign in favor of the\"Leave\"campaign,¹⁰¹ many others agree that such Russian ⁹³. President Joe Biden, Remarks on Russia at the Presidential Briefing Room (Apr. 15, 2021), https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/speeches-remarks/2021/04/15/remarks-by-president-biden-on-russia/.\nMEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW87 # THE PROHIBITION OF INTERVENTIONS IN THE INTERNAL AFFAIRS OF OTHER STATES The prohibition on interventions Customary international law prohibits interventions in other states' internal affairs.¹²⁵ The 1933 Montevideo Convention includes the provision that\"[n]o state has the right to intervene in the internal or external affairs of another,\"¹²⁶ and Article 2(7) of the 1945 UN Charter even rules out UN intervention in a member state's internal affairs.¹²⁷ By the 1960s, there was broad international consensus on the prohibition of interventions in another state's internal affairs.¹²⁸ This is confirmed by the 1965 General Assembly Declaration on the Inadmissibility of Intervention in the Domestic Affairs of States and the Protection of their Independence and Sovereignty¹²⁹ and its 1970 Declaration on Principles of International Law concerning Friendly Relations and Cooperation among States (Friendly Relations Resolution); the latter reaffirmed that\"[n]o State or group of States has the right to intervene, directly or indirectly, for any reason whatever, in the internal or external affairs of any other State.\"¹³⁰ Although the General Assembly's resolutions were not legally binding,¹³¹ their passage supports the argument that states viewed the declarations as reflecting international legal rules.¹³² In 2005, the ICJ INTERNATIONAL LAW 89, 102–03 (Malcom D. Evans ed., 5th ed. 2018).\n\nINDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2 confirmed that the Friendly Relations Resolution was “declaratory of customary international law.”¹³³ The ICJ itself had previously stressed the legal quality of the prohibition of such interventions: already in 1949, it declared interventions in other states’ affairs to be unlawful.¹³⁴ The prohibition on interventions in the internal or external affairs of another state therefore qualifies as a rule of customary international law.¹³⁵ The ICJ’s 1986 judgment in the Nicaragua case is frequently cited when discussing the prohibition of interventions because the court provided a partial definition of the prohibition’s scope. Reaffirming the principle of nonintervention as a rule of customary international law,¹³⁶ the ICJ went on to define a prohibited intervention: A prohibited intervention must accordingly be one bearing on matters in which each State is permitted, by the principle of State sovereignty to decide freely. One of these is the choice of a political, economic, social and cultural system, and the formulation of foreign policy. Intervention is wrongful when it uses methods of coercion in regard to such choices, which must remain free ones.¹³⁷ Thus, unlawful intervention consists of two elements. The intervenor must be targeting another state’s internal or external affairs or, as the ICJ phrased it, “matters in which each state is permitted...\nYost, said the resolution had “the precise job of enunciating that law” as far as non-intervention was concerned); see also Legality of the Threat or Use of Nuclear Weapons, Advisory Opinion, 1996 I.C.J. Rep. 226, ¶ 70 (July 8).\n¹³³. Armed Activities on the Territory of the Congo (Dem. Rep. Congo v. Uganda), 2005 I.C.J. Rep. 168, ¶ 162 (Dec. 19).\n¹³⁴. See The Corfu Channel Case (U.K. v.
