    "MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW87\n\n# THE PROHIBITION OF INTERVENTIONS IN THE INTERNAL AFFAIRS OF OTHER STATES\n\nThe prohibition on interventions\n\nCustomary international law prohibits interventions in other states' internal affairs.¹²⁵ The 1933 Montevideo Convention includes the provision that \"[n]o state has the right to intervene in the internal or external affairs of another,\"¹²⁶ and Article 2(7) of the 1945 UN Charter even rules out UN intervention in a member state's internal affairs.¹²⁷ By the 1960s, there was broad international consensus on the prohibition of interventions in another state's internal affairs.¹²⁸ This is confirmed by the 1965 General Assembly Declaration on the Inadmissibility of Intervention in the Domestic Affairs of States and the Protection of their Independence and Sovereignty¹²⁹ and its 1970 Declaration on Principles of International Law concerning Friendly Relations and Cooperation among States (Friendly Relations Resolution); the latter reaffirmed that \"[n]o State or group of States has the right to intervene, directly or indirectly, for any reason whatever, in the internal or external affairs of any other State.\"¹³⁰\n\nAlthough the General Assembly's resolutions were not legally binding,¹³¹ their passage supports the argument that states viewed the declarations as reflecting international legal rules.¹³² In 2005, the ICJ\n\n125.     "INDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2\n\nconfirmed that the Friendly Relations Resolution was “declaratory of customary international law.”¹³³ The ICJ itself had previously stressed the legal quality of the prohibition of such interventions: already in 1949, it declared interventions in other states’ affairs to be unlawful.¹³⁴ The prohibition on interventions in the internal or external affairs of another state therefore qualifies as a rule of customary international law.¹³⁵\n\nThe ICJ’s 1986 judgment in the Nicaragua case is frequently cited when discussing the prohibition of interventions because the court provided a partial definition of the prohibition’s scope. Reaffirming the principle of nonintervention as a rule of customary international law,¹³⁶ the ICJ went on to define a prohibited intervention:\n\nA prohibited intervention must accordingly be one bearing on matters in which each State is permitted, by the principle of State sovereignty to decide freely. One of these is the choice of a political, economic, social and cultural system, and the formulation of foreign policy. Intervention is wrongful when it uses methods of coercion in regard to such choices, which must remain free ones.¹³⁷\n\nThus, unlawful intervention consists of two elements. The intervenor must be targeting another state’s internal or external affairs or, as the ICJ phrased it, “matters in which each state is permitted . . .\n\nYost, said the resolution had “the precise job of enunciating that law” as far as non-intervention was concerned); see also Legality of the Threat or Use of Nuclear Weapons, Advisory Opinion, 1996 I.C.J.     "MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW89\n\nto decide freely.\"¹³⁸ These matters are sometimes referred to as the domaine réservé,¹³⁹ which, as the ICJ explained, definitely includes \"the choice of a political, economic, social and cultural system and the formulation of foreign policy.\"¹⁴⁰ However, not every state activity in respect of another state's internal affairs is unlawful. Rather, the intervenor must employ \"methods of coercion\" to achieve its aims.¹⁴¹ When analyzing the definition the ICJ provided, it becomes evident that acts of persuasion cannot be unlawful even when they concern other states' internal affairs.¹⁴² To \"persuade\" has been defined as \"to cause people to do or believe something, esp[ecially] by explaining why they should.\"¹⁴³ As persuasion therefore lacks the coercive element demanded by the ICJ, state activities that aim to persuade a target state (or its electorate) to take a specific course of action cannot amount to unlawful intervention.¹⁴⁴\n\nHowever, distinguishing lawful persuasion from unlawful intervention is not as straightforward as it might seem.¹⁴⁵ This confusion arises because there is disagreement on the definition of the term \"coercion\" in international law.¹⁴⁶ Some claim the ICJ's reference to \"methods of coercion\" severely limits the scope of the prohibition on interventions.¹⁴⁷ According to this view, intervention is only prohibited\n\n138.     "INDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2\n\nwhen the level of coercion is comparable to the threat to use force.¹⁴⁸ The inaccuracy of this view becomes obvious when some claim that coercive intervention must be “dictatorial” in nature, leaving the target state with no room for maneuver,¹⁴⁹ and that coercion requires the target state to be fully aware of its being coerced.¹⁵⁰\n\nThis very limited view of prohibited interventions is unconvincing.¹⁵¹ When partially defining the term “nonintervention,” the ICJ stressed it was only looking at “those aspects of the principle which appear to be relevant” to the case before it.¹⁵² The court was dealing with the United States’ massive support of the Nicaraguan rebels, the Contras, who were attempting to overthrow their country’s government by force. There was no need to explore the issue of “coercion” in any detail.¹⁵³ The United States’ involvement in the rebels’ use of force was undoubtedly coercive regarding Nicaragua’s system of government.¹⁵⁴ The fact that the ICJ did not provide a more concise definition of prohibited interventions,¹⁵⁵ therefore, does not mean that less coercive means are permissible. Rather, the difference between coercive intervention and permissible persuasion comes down to whether the target state retains its freedom to choose in matters related to its independence as a state.¹⁵⁶\n\nsupra note 138 (offering a general discussion of the difficulty of distinguishing between acceptable “persuasion” of another state and unlawful “coercion”).\n\n148. For the purposes of Article 18, coercion “has the same essential character as force majeure,” “giving it [the target state] no effective choice but to comply with the wishes of the coercing state.” Id. at 69. However, the ILC repeatedly emphasized that this “narrow,” definition only applied “for the purpose of Article 18.” Id. at 69–70. Article 18’s scope is narrow as it only applies to the coercing state’s responsibility under international law for an unlawful act committed by the coerced state.     "MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW91\n\nThus, an intervention is unlawful when the aim is to deprive the target state of its discretion to decide freely on issues related to its internal or external affairs.¹⁵⁷ As DeWitt Dickinson indicated in 1920, intervention is prohibited when it “cannot be terminated at the pleasure of the state that is subject to the intervention.”¹⁵⁸ Coercion, thus, merely requires that the target state is unable to respond to the outside interference and is therefore forced to tolerate it, irrespective of whether this tolerance is due to inability or lack of awareness. In both cases, the target state is robbed of its ability to defend itself against foreign meddling in its affairs.\n\nThis is a far more convincing definition than demanding “dictatorial interference” with the strong implication that an intervention needs to rise almost to the level of the use of force to be unlawful,¹⁵⁹ consequently allowing powerful foreign states to intervene in other states’ affairs as long as it could plausibly be claimed that the target state still retained some discretion, however hypothetical, to make a choice in its internal or external matters.¹⁶⁰ Applying the standard of “dictatorial interference,” even to the events in Nicaragua, arguably would result in the conclusion that the United States did not violate the prohibition on intervention. After all, the government of Nicaragua was able to resist the activities of both the United States and the Contras for many years.¹⁶¹ Consequently, it is arguable that the government of Nicaragua retained its freedom of choice.¹⁶² Furthermore, the term “intervention”—in contrast to, for example, imposition—implies the possibility of some discretion remaining on the part of the target state.¹⁶³ In summary, equating prohibited intervention with dictatorial interference is unacceptable if the prohibition on outside interventions is to have any meaning.\n\nSome claim that a state can only be coerced if it is aware of the intervenor’s activities and thus aware of its being coerced by it.¹⁶⁴ This\n\n157.     "INDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2\n\nexcludes from the prohibition all activities by the intervening state of which the target state is not aware. This, too, is an unnecessary and unconvincing limitation of the prohibition on interventions.¹⁶⁵ Applied to the US activities in Nicaragua, this would imply that the US support of the Contras would have been lawful as long as Nicaragua was not aware of American activities and continued to blame the Contras' activities solely on this domestic opponent.¹⁶⁶ On the other hand, such activities would become unlawful the moment the target state became aware of the foreign intervenor's involvement. This unsatisfactory distinction between lawful and unlawful activities evidences that awareness on the part of the target state is not a suitable criterion to differentiate between lawful activities and unlawful coercion.¹⁶⁷ This is also confirmed by opinio juris: both the United States and the United Kingdom have declared that the manipulation of election results by cyber means is an unlawful intervention in the target state's internal affairs.¹⁶⁸ This view is widely supported,¹⁶⁹ but is incompatible with the view that a state must be aware of the coercion for the intervention to be unlawful.\n\nLastly, it is sometimes claimed that the prohibition on interventions is very difficult to apply in practice, as it often remains unclear whether the intervention was successful or not.¹⁷⁰ For example, some have argued that the Russian meddling in the US presidential election of 2016 cannot be judged as unlawful, as it remained uncertain whether these activities actually influenced the outcome of the election.¹⁷¹ This\n\n165.     "MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW93\n\nargument is similarly unconvincing. Whether a state's actions are successful or not does not determine their lawfulness.¹⁷² Applied to the US activities in Nicaragua, such an understanding of unlawful interventions would require an assessment as to whether supporting the Contras' military campaign was successful in compelling the Nicaraguan government to comply with US demands.¹⁷³ Interpreting the prohibition in such a way would lead to an even greater proliferation of coercive interventions, as states would not be acting unlawfully as long as the intervention remained unsuccessful.¹⁷⁴ Failure or, as in the case of Russian election meddling, the lack of proof of a causal relationship between the intervention and its success would thus imply that the intervenor was acting lawfully. Such an interpretation is clearly inadequate.¹⁷⁵\n\nFor an intervention to be judged unlawful it is, nevertheless, not sufficient to conclude that the intervenor employed coercive methods. Even coercive interventions in another state's internal matters can be lawful as long as the intervenor resorts to means that he is entitled to under public international law. This phenomenon is especially true in the case of economic penalties and benefits.     "INDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2\n\nIn summary, intervention is usually unlawful when a state is targeting the internal affairs of another state and thereby employing methods that the target state cannot \"terminate at its pleasure\"¹⁸⁰ and therefore are coercive. It is not necessary for the interference to be dictatorial in nature, nor need the state be aware of its being coerced. Furthermore, the success of the intervention is not a valid criterion under public international law. In order to reach a definitive verdict, however, it also needs to be ascertained that the intervening state was not acting within its rights under public international law when resorting to coercion.\n\n## Prohibited interventions in other states' elections\n\n\"In addition, I would be in favor of legislation prohibiting interference with the electoral processes in other countries.\"¹⁸¹\n\nCyrus Vance thus expressed his wish for US legislation outlawing foreign election meddling. The United States itself has long been intolerant of foreign interference in its political deliberations; to combat just such foreign meddling, the Foreign Agents Registration Act (FARA) was enacted in 1938.¹⁸² Explaining why it deemed the FARA necessary, the Committee on the Judiciary of the House of Representatives declared:\n\nIncontrovertible evidence has been submitted to prove that there are many persons in the United States representing foreign governments or foreign political groups, who are supplied by such foreign agencies with funds and other materials to foster un-American activities, and to influence the external and internal policies of this country, thereby violating both the letter and the spirit of international law. . . .\n\nThis required registration will publicize the nature of subversive or other similar activities so that the American people may know those who are engaged in this country by foreign agencies to spread doctrines alien to our democratic form of government, or propaganda for\n\n180. See Dickinson, supra note 158; Tsagourias, supra note 158.\n181. Hearings Before the Select Committee to Study Governmental Operations with Respect to Intelligence Activities, 94th Cong. 54 (1975) (statements of Cyrus Vance).\n182. Foreign Agents Registration Act (FARA), 22 U.S.C. §§ 611–21.",
    "MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW95\n\nthe purpose of influencing American public opinion on a political question.¹⁸³\n\nElections determine a people’s “choice of a political, economic, social and cultural system, and the formulation of foreign policy,” a decision which, according to the ICJ, must remain free.¹⁸⁴ There is, therefore, widespread agreement that a state’s electoral process is a matter within a state’s *domaine réservé* and is protected by the prohibition on interventions.¹⁸⁵ This protection is confirmed by numerous General Assembly resolutions that have stated that:\n\n[A]ny activities that attempt, directly or indirectly, to interfere in the free development of national electoral processes, in particular in the developing countries, or that are intended to sway the results of such processes, violate the spirit and letter of the principles established in the Charter and in the Declaration on Principles of International Law concerning Friendly Relations and Cooperation among States in accordance with the Charter of the United Nations.¹⁸⁶\n\nFurthermore, the fact that intervenors often seem to succeed in influencing target-state election results,¹⁸⁷ thereby securing for themselves a say in choosing a target state’s government, renders any contrary arguments unconvincing. As Ray Meyer has pointed out, such an intervention, if successful, can result in “an inherently more extensive intervention in internal affairs because it may involve an indirect intervention in all future policy decisions made by the tainted\n\n183.     "INDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2\n\ngovernment.”¹⁸⁸\n\n## Persuasion\n\nAccordingly, the main emphasis of legal analysis must focus on whether the intervenor employed coercive means in order to achieve the desired election result.¹⁸⁹ As indicated earlier, the attempt by one state to persuade another state’s electorate to vote in a specific way is lawful under public international law.¹⁹⁰ What differentiates lawful persuasion from unlawful intervention is the decision on the part of the meddling state, in the former case, to forego coercive methods. Thus, it is perfectly acceptable for a state to criticize another state’s government or to publicly announce its preferences as to an election outcome in another state, including via its resident diplomats in the target state.¹⁹¹ The same is true of broadcasts on that state’s television and radio networks or reports and editorials in newspapers there, even if instigated by the intervening government.¹⁹² These criticisms or announcements are not in any way coercive, as the target state and the electorate can respond by, for example, rejecting or agreeing with the arguments put forward by the intervenor. Furthermore, the target state’s electorate is fully aware of the endorsement’s source and can evaluate it accordingly. Such actions lack a coercive element and are therefore lawful.¹⁹³\n\n## Deception and Manipulation\n\nSuch interference turns coercive, however, when methods of deception and manipulation are introduced into the equation.¹⁹⁴ Bribing target-state journalists to support the foreign government’s policies in\n\n188.     "MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW97\n\nreports and editorials or posting political views on social media under the guise of being a target-state citizen is thus unlawful.¹⁹⁵ The difference from the situation described above hinges on the definition of coercion: this kind of deceit leaves the target state defenseless against the foreign intervention. The target state cannot terminate it “at its pleasure” since target-state citizens or journalists are well within their rights when expressing their views publicly.¹⁹⁶ Furthermore, voters in the target state are misled into believing that the intervening country’s views are put forward by fellow citizens, and these voters will almost certainly pay more attention to such opinions than they would to easily identifiable foreign interference.¹⁹⁷ The intervenor’s activities, in truth, amount to nothing else but a secret election campaign in support of the preferred candidates. The strategy on the part of the intervening state demonstrates the coercive intent—it chooses to hide the origin of the views expressed in print, on air, or online in order to deceive the target state and its voters and to prevent the target state from responding.¹⁹⁸ The coercion towards the target state manifests itself in the intervening state’s active participation in another state’s election campaign, conducted in a way that the target state cannot prevent or terminate. As Dov Levin has concluded, “a covert intervention carries far lower chances of a backlash due to the inherent secrecy in the provision of the electoral aid.”¹⁹⁹ An overt intervention, on the other hand, may “lead to a backlash against the preferred candidate, hurting rather than helping their chances of being elected.”²⁰⁰\n\nIf the intervenor’s aim is not only to secure the preferred election outcome but also to undermine public trust in the electoral process more generally, as claimed in the case of the Russian meddling in the 2016 US election,²⁰¹ the coercive intent becomes even more obvious. The intervenor is seeking to subvert the target state’s system of government by way of deception, which renders the target state defenseless as long as the deception is not uncovered.²⁰² On the other hand, should the deception be uncovered, the public may well view an election outcome as illegitimate—in the belief that foreign meddling influenced the results—which undermines the public’s trust in its government and is therefore\n\n195.     "INDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2\n\nsimilarly subversive.²⁰³\n\n## Disseminating false or true information\n\nHaving thus identified the line where lawful persuasion becomes unlawful intervention, it is obvious that more serious activities, such as spreading fake news or forging documents in order to influence the target state's election outcome, are clearly unlawful.²⁰⁴ Although spreading disinformation may possibly lead to a target-state response, the intervenor's intention is to avoid an effective target-state reaction and to deceive that state's electorate. A more difficult issue to address is whether spreading true information is similarly unlawful.²⁰⁵ Whether such activities are unlawful is dependent on how the information was obtained and when it was disseminated. No matter how the information was obtained, it is unlawful for a foreign state to intentionally disseminate true information on the eve of an election²⁰⁶ with the aim of preventing a meaningful response on the part of the target state or its politicians in order to influence the outcome of the target state's elections.²⁰⁷ After all, even correct information can be taken out of context or instrumentalized in order to insinuate false allegations. The intervenor's intention to avoid scrutiny and ward off any reaction on the target state's part makes the interference coercive.\n\nAs far as the spreading of true information gained by way of\n\n203.     "MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW99\n\nespionage is concerned, this, too, constitutes unlawful intervention.²⁰⁸ Illicitly gained information is instrumentalized in order to influence the target state’s election results in a meaningful way.²⁰⁹ The fact that the information was gained by way of espionage taints the dissemination of the information. The intervenor’s intent to manipulate the outcome of the election, and to therefore intervene in the target state’s internal affairs by using the material obtained by deceit and manipulation, causes the act of espionage to be unlawful.²¹⁰ Here, too, the target state is not able to terminate either the espionage or the subsequent dissemination of the information, which makes such actions coercive in nature.²¹¹\n\nWhat remains is the dissemination—in a timely manner—of true information gained by lawful means. If, for example, the relevant information can be found in open sources (such as a candidate’s old posts on Facebook) it is lawful for the interfering state to spread such information, although such action may well have a noticeable impact on the election outcome in the target state.²¹² This is due to the fact that such action is persuasive in nature—the intervenor is utilizing lawfully obtained material in order to persuade target-state voters to vote in a specific way.²¹³ As dissemination in a timely manner is a prerequisite, both the target state and the target state’s politicians have the opportunity to respond to any possible allegations.\n\n208.     "INDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2\n\n## Funding political parties and/or candidates\n\nFunding parties or candidates and their election campaigns in another state, the most favored form of foreign intervention,²¹⁴ is unlawful.²¹⁵ The unlawfulness is particularly obvious when foreign funding of parties and candidates is prohibited in the target state.²¹⁶ In this context, funding is meant to include the training of target-state citizens in campaigning or producing campaigning materials for the preferred candidate. Here, too, the target state is unable to terminate the intervention at its pleasure. By enabling the preferred politicians to outspend their rivals—often by wide margins²¹⁷—the intervenor clearly is attempting to install a government favorable to its own goals that may well even be beholden to it due to the support received.\n\n## Intrusion on the electoral process itself\n\nThe most severe kind of intervention in the sphere of election meddling is, of course, the manipulation of the electoral process itself.²¹⁸ Changing election results; making ballots disappear; deleting or adding names to the electoral register; or manipulating electronic voting machines, the \"electoral doomsday scenario,\"²¹⁹ are undoubtedly coercive in nature.²²⁰ The target state is not meant to notice the manipulation\n\n214.     "MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW101\n\nand is therefore unable to terminate the intervention and the manipulation. If successful, this manipulation might well lead to the imposition of a government by outsiders, irrespective of the electorate's wishes. Short of the use of force, this amounts to the most coercive intrusion into another state's electoral process.\n\n## Preclusion of the intervention's wrongfulness / Justifications\n\nThe possibility, however, remains that the target state has granted its consent to the foreign intervention. It is widely agreed that valid consent precludes the intervention's wrongfulness.²²¹ In the context of election meddling, the question arises whether the governing party could grant such consent on behalf of the state to a foreign intervention intended to keep it in power. That is not the case. Generally, a government's consent on behalf of a state is sufficient.²²² Nevertheless, in such cases it is obvious to both sides, the governing party and the intervenor, that consent is not being granted on behalf of the state but on behalf of the political party that is in power at that moment.²²³ The officials tolerating or agreeing to such outside intervention are not acting as representatives of the state but rather as representatives of a political party.²²⁴ A political party's agreement, even if it should be the currently governing party, to outside intervention is therefore not sufficient to preclude the intervention's unlawfulness.²²⁵\n\nIrrespective of the foregoing legal analysis, some authors argue that the legality of interventions in another state's electoral process should also be judged according to the intervenor's goals.²²⁶ Should the\n\nCyber Capabilities and the International Law of Sovereignty and Intervention, 96 INT'L L.     "MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW105\n\nconsequences or the promise of economic benefits, as well as the intervening state's conduct, are arguably facts that voters should be considering when casting their vote.\n\n## Summary\n\nA state is free to interfere during another state's election campaign as long as its intent is persuasive rather than coercive. Issuing statements in support of one of the competing parties, instigating editorials in domestic newspapers, or broadcasting reports supportive of a candidate are lawful. The target state can respond, and the electorate can evaluate such information correctly. It is also lawful to disseminate true information in a timely manner so long as the intervenor obtained it in a lawful fashion.\n\nOnce a state resorts to deceit and manipulation in order to disguise its intentions, the intervention becomes unlawful, as the target state cannot terminate the interference. The intervening state is thereby actively, but often covertly, participating in the target state's election campaign in such a way that the intervenor hopes the target state cannot prevent or terminate. Funding foreign political parties or intervening in the electoral process itself is similarly coercive in nature and violates the prohibition on interventions. Nevertheless, any prospective intervenor has a powerful tool at its disposal—although also clearly coercive, the threat to sever, or the promise to enhance, economic relations is lawful, as such decisions are at every state's, the intervenor's included, discretion.\n\n## A brief legal analysis of the interventions in 1948 and 2016\n\nApplied to the 1948 election in Italy and the 2016 election in the United States, the foregoing analysis leads to the following assessment: official statements on the part of US officials in the run-up to the Italian election in 1948, which statements advised against voting for the Communist Party, were lawful, as their aim was to persuade rather than coerce. Similarly, the broadcasts, such as those by the Voice of America, described above (which broadcasts were accessible in Italy) or through Russian-origin television programs on RT or Sputnik, even though biased and perhaps influential, were not unlawful either. Similarly, the intent of the massive letter-writing campaign organized in the United States among Italian Americans was persuasive rather than coercive.\n\nThe forging of documents, the bribing of Italian journalists, and the massive funding of center-right parties in Italy were unlawful, as were",
    "INDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2\n\nthe efforts by the Russian government to initiate and maintain a social media campaign in favor of Trump utilizing fake American identities. The hacking of e-mails originating from leaders within Clinton's Democratic Party, and the subsequent disclosure of the information, were unlawful because they were gained by unlawful espionage in order to achieve an unlawful aim—namely, having a say in another state's election outcome. Without more details, it is difficult to judge whether the US disclosures as far as Italian politicians' personal lives are concerned were lawful or unlawful—that depends on how the information was obtained and whether the stories disseminated were true or false. Lastly, possibly the most coercive instruments used by the United States, the threat to stop economic aid to Italy and the promise of further economic support dependent on the Italian election results, were lawful, as was the threat to bar Communist-supporting Italians from entering the United States, because these measures were within the United States' rights as an independent state conducting its external affairs.\n\n## THE VIOLATION OF SOVEREIGNTY\n\nIntervening in another state's election can also imply a violation of that state's sovereignty.     "MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW109\n\nSimilarly, the manipulation of voting machines located on the target state's territory, whether remotely or not, will violate the target state's sovereignty, as the target state's governmental authority is being usurped.²⁵⁵ Some forms of cyber activity, such as the hacking of e-mails stored on servers located within the target state's territory, will also involve an unlawful disregard of that state's sovereignty.²⁵⁶\n\nNevertheless, basing the unlawfulness of election meddling solely on the violation of the target state's sovereignty has significant drawbacks, as many of the interventions described above would consequently be lawful.²⁵⁷ If a state funds a foreign political party or candidate with the potential effect of massively influencing the outcome of the target state's election, there are many possible scenarios that do not involve a violation of the target state's sovereignty.²⁵⁸ Basically, it would be sufficient to hand over any monies on the intervenor's territory to avoid any violation of international law. Similarly, many of the cyber activities mentioned above, such as posting political messages under the guise of being a target-state citizen, cannot plausibly be argued to violate the target state's sovereignty so long as the activity is conducted from outside the target state's territory.²⁵⁹ Also, some forms of cyber espionage do not violate the target state's sovereignty, such as intercepting e-mails during transmission or obtaining e-mails stored on servers located outside of the target state's territory.²⁶⁰\n\nIn summary, although the violation of the target state's sovereignty is often implicated when discussing election meddling, there are many instances of such behavior that cannot be construed as interfering with the target state's exclusive authority within its territory.²⁶¹ Furthermore, the reliance on a sovereignty violation also does not address the one issue the prohibition on interventions does not resolve: threatening economic consequences in the case of an unfavorable election outcome does not violate the target state's sovereignty but is rather an expression of the intervenor's sovereignty. Therefore, the prohibition on violating other states' sovereignty is less relevant to the\n\n255.     "INDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2\n\ndiscussion of election meddling than the prohibition on interventions in the internal matters of other states.\n\n## THE RIGHT OF SELF-DETERMINATION\n\nMore recently, Jens David Ohlin has suggested another line of argument. According to him, election meddling, such as the actions the Russians are accused of in relation to the 2016 US presidential election, violates the collective right of self-determination of the target state's people.²⁶² By implication, Ohlin suggests that the prohibition of such actions may be limited to cases where the states targeted are democracies.²⁶³\n\nThis line of reasoning is not convincing for a number of reasons. Most scholars responding to Ohlin's arguments have pointed out that the right of self-determination has so far not been viewed as applicable to already existent states.²⁶⁴ Rather, the counterargument goes, the right of self-determination has traditionally only been granted to peoples in the process of decolonization.²⁶⁵ More recently, in light of the Canadian Supreme Court's groundbreaking judgment on a possible secession by Québec,²⁶⁶ some have argued that a right of external self-determination could apply to a people suffering internal discrimination within an existent state.²⁶⁷ Sovereign states though, the argument concludes, cannot lay claim to a right of self-determination.²⁶⁸\n\nAlthough the arguments just set out do have some merit, I agree with Ohlin that a people living within an already existent state does have a right of self-determination that can be violated.²⁶⁹ There is no reason to believe that the right of self-determination automatically ceases to exist once a people has managed to organize itself in an\n\n262. INT'L L. 162, 183–85 (2009) (positing that foreign election meddling endangers the “interest in self-government”).\n263. Ohlen, supra note 10, at 97.\n264.     "MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW111\n\nindependent state.²⁷⁰ However, that right of self-determination of a people in an existent state is already protected by the prohibition on interventions.²⁷¹ The prohibition on coercive interventions in matters that each state can decide freely also serves to protect that state's people's right of self-determination.²⁷² As the ICJ has explained, an intervention is unlawful when it bears on matters such as \"the choice of a political, economic, social and cultural system, and the formulation of foreign policy.\"²⁷³ As James Crawford has explained, \"Where a self-determination unit is a State, the principle of self-determination is represented by the rule against intervention in the internal affairs of that State, and in particular in the choice of the form of government of the State.\"²⁷⁴ Thus, prohibited interventions are interventions that (also) violate the target-state people's right of self-determination.²⁷⁵\n\nFurthermore, Ohlin's arguments have little prospect of acceptance as a rule of customary international law due to their implied reliance on the target state's \"democratic\" structures. Rather, sovereignty and the prohibition on interventions certainly overlap insofar as the intervenor is interfering with the target state's right to govern within its territory. However, a prohibited intervention can take place that, for example, aims to severely disrupt the target state's foreign or trade policy. Such an intervention would not necessarily violate the target state's sovereignty, as it does not need to take place on its territory and does not have to amount to a usurpation of the target state's governmental functions within that territory. Thus, violating another state's sovereignty and intervening in its domain réservé are both unlawful, but at times distinct offenses. See also Van de Velde, supra note 10, at 15.\n\n272.     "INDIANA JOURNAL OF GLOBAL LEGAL STUDIES 29:2\n\nConsequently, such a rule has so far not been accepted,²⁸⁶ and will most likely not be accepted by a majority of states.\n\nIn summary, there is no need to rely on a right of self-determination as far as existent states are concerned, as their peoples' right of self-determination is sufficiently protected by the prohibition on interventions in the internal affairs of other states. Furthermore, the way Ohlin seems to want to apply such a right—namely, by offering protection only to democratic systems as understood mainly in the United States—has no chance of being accepted as a rule of customary international law, as non-Western states are bound to reject the creation of a rule that gives the impression of being self-serving.\n\n## CONCLUSION\n\nThis article set out to examine the lawfulness of foreign election meddling in public international law. I began by describing two such events in the past in more detail—the US interference in the Italian election of 1948 and the Russian activities in relation to the US election in 2016. I then briefly addressed a few other instances of US or Russian election interference. These examples served to illustrate that it has always been possible to become heavily involved in other states' elections and that states have done so in different ways. Past US interference in other states' elections may help explain US President Obama's ambiguous statement regarding Russian election meddling in 2016, when he declared such actions as Russian \"efforts to undermine international norms of behavior.\"²⁸⁷ Subsequently, I analyzed whether such election meddling is compatible with public international law and argued that the prohibition on interventions in other states' internal affairs is the decisive rule of international law when trying to establish whether a specific action amounts to a violation of international law. There is widespread agreement that elections are among the matters protected by the prohibition on interventions.²⁸⁸ The subsequent analysis therefore centered on the question of whether specific actions\n\n286.     "MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW115\n\ncan be classified as “methods of coercion.” The term “coercion” obviously excludes from the prohibition means of persuasion.²⁸⁹ Therefore, it is, for example, not unlawful for a state to publicly state its preferences as to the outcome of an election in another state.²⁹⁰ The interfering state is thereby simply advocating an outcome that it believes to be in its national interest. The target state and its people remain free to decide whether and how to respond.\n\nSuch persuasion, however, morphs into coercion if the intervenor employs deception or manipulation in order to promote its self-interest during another state’s election campaign.²⁹¹ Although messages posted on social media may be persuasive rather than coercive in content, the fact that the intervenor disguises these posts’ origin by implying that they reflect views held by target-state citizens makes them coercive, as the target state cannot respond to, much less terminate, such interference at its pleasure. It is the target state’s helplessness in the face of such interference that is the driving force behind the intervenor’s deception. The intervening state actively participates in another state’s election campaign in a way that the target cannot respond to, much less prevent or terminate. This therefore amounts to coercive interference. It follows that more intrusive election meddling, such as spreading fake news, (cyber) espionage, and funding political parties and individual politicians, as well as disrupting the target state’s electoral process, certainly meet the threshold of a prohibited intervention.²⁹² This threshold is even more clearly met if the intervenor’s goal is to undermine the public’s trust in the target state’s electoral process.²⁹³\n\nHowever, the analysis also revealed that one of the most coercive interventions in another state’s election is lawful. The threat to sever economic ties or, conversely, the promise of economic benefits dependent on the election result is potentially extremely coercive as far as voters\n\n289. Given that maintaining, enhancing, or discontinuing economic ties with another state is widely seen as an issue at every state's sovereign discretion, it follows that such economic coercion, nevertheless, remains lawful.²⁹⁴ In such instances, it could even plausibly be argued that the intervenor is providing target-state citizens with information they may wish to consider when deciding who to vote for. Lastly, the application of these rules to the instances of election meddling in Italy in 1948 and the United States in 2016 confirms that the prohibition on interventions enables a comprehensive legal analysis of foreign interference in elections.\n\nAfter explaining the central role of the prohibition on interventions when judging the lawfulness of election meddling, I briefly set out why I believe the two other rules of international law that are invoked in this context are less satisfactory.     "MEDDLING IN FOREIGN ELECTIONS AND PUBLIC INTERNATIONAL LAW117\n\nseems to want to limit the application of the right of self-determination to democracies as understood in mainly Western and allied societies. It follows that there is no chance of such a rule being accepted as customary international law by a majority of states.\n\nMany forms of election meddling are unlawful and violate the prohibition on interventions in other states' internal affairs. The fact that economic coercion remains lawful, however, renders the prohibition much less effective. Of course, it would be beneficial if clear international rules could be developed that outline which conduct is permissible in respect of other states' elections. Now that powerful states such as the United States are themselves vulnerable to potentially decisive foreign election meddling, there may even be a unique opportunity to develop such legal guidelines. That kind of discussion is urgently needed, as the danger of massive interventions in foreign elections is growing rapidly due to the vast possibilities the internet offers.     "abstract": "A state is free to interfere during another state's election campaign as long as its intent is persuasive rather than coercive. Issuing statements in support of one of the competing parties, instigating editorials in domestic newspapers, or broadcasting reports supportive of a candidate are lawful. The target state can respond, and the electorate can evaluate such information correctly. It is also lawful to disseminate true information in a timely manner so long as the intervenor obtained it in a lawful fashion. Once a state resorts to deceit and manipulation in order to disguise its intentions, the intervention becomes unlawful, as the target state cannot terminate the interference. The intervening state is thereby actively, but often covertly, participating in the target state's election campaign in such a way that the intervenor hopes the target state cannot prevent or terminate. Funding foreign political parties or intervening in the electoral process itself is similarly coercive in nature and violates the prohibition on interventions. Nevertheless, any prospective intervenor has a powerful tool at its disposal—although also clearly coercive, the threat to sever, or the promise to enhance, economic relations is lawful, as such decisions are at every state's, the intervenor's included, discretion.",
